Description.val:
This Budget Line Item funds The Unmanned Carrier Aviation (UCA) Mission Control System (UMCS) program. This program builds, integrates, installs, and sustains control systems required to operate the MQ-25 and other ship installation associated with MQ-25.

UMCS builds the following hardware: the MQ-25 control station, the Video Management System (VidMS), ARC-210 the Radio Communication System (RCS), and the Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) capable communication system.  The control station has 2 variants, 1 for the CVN and another for shore, designated the MD-5A and MD-5B, respectively.  An MD-5 consists of 6 Common Display System (CDS) workstations, 2 Common Processing System (CPS) racks, 1 Network Processing Group (NPG) rack, which includes the Network Attached Storage (NAS) hardware to provide redundancy for the CPS, 1 Integrated Communication System (ICS) and software.  The MD-5A and MD-5B use the same hardware with the exception of the ICS, which has CVN and shore variants, software, and networking and data transmission systems.  The MD-5B requires dedicated Common Data Link (CDL) terminals and an Ashore Routing Communication System (ARCS) which integrates with NAVWAR's Automated Digital Network System (ADNS).  The VidMS provides MQ-25 air vehicle operators with situational awareness of the unmanned carrier environment.  The ARC-210 RCS provides narrow band Line of Sight (LOS) command and control (C2) for the MQ-25 while the MUOS communication system provides narrow band Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) C2 using the MUOS satellites. The shore variants of the ARC-210 and MUOS communication systems leverage the CVN variant.  UMCS government personnel perform the Lead Systems Integrator (LSI) role across all the hardware and software systems within UMCS, which includes assembly, integration, system checkout and delivery.  UMCS integrates with the MQ-25 air vehicle, local networks, voice networks, C2 networks, tactical networks, intelligence systems, and launch and recovery systems. The government also performs the LSI role between the control systems listed in the aforementioned paragraph and the externally managed systems required for MQ-25 operations.

UMCS performs CVN infrastructure modifications and installs the hardware described above in support of MQ-25 operations aboard NIMITZ and FORD Class carriers, as well as the 3 fixed operational shore sites.  The CONUS operational shore sites each have 2 MD-5B control stations while the OCONUS location has 1 MD-5B control station. All installation and integration activities aboard NIMITZ and FORD class carriers are planned and executed using the NAVSEA Ship Change Document (SCD) process. These installation and integration activities are conducted serially across multiple CVN Availability periods (at least two depending upon the length of the planned shipyard maintenance period) where each availability period is preceded by three years of labor and material procurement in accordance with the NAVSEA process that identify strict delivery schedules for documentation, drawings, and hardware.  The CVN availability schedule is updated at least twice per year and drives UMCS planning, modifications, and installations. Typically, CVN Installations are executed in four phases. Phase 1 begins with the SCD planning and technical data preparation three years prior to availability. Phase 2 begins with a hull specific Ship Check, development of detailed Ship Installation Drawings (SIDs), and procurement of hardware two years prior to the next CVN availability period. Phase 3 starts one-year prior to the availability and includes approval of the final design, the SIDs, and cybersecurity/logistics documentation.  Finally, Phase 4 is installation during the availability period.  Due to the size and complexity of the UMCS modifications at least two six-month schedule maintenance periods are required.  Installation and integration activities at the operational shore site are planned and executed via a method similar to the SCD process tailored to shore facilities.


The MD-5 control station production effort includes production planning (methodology), non-recurring engineering (NRE) for the MD-5 control station, quality plan and procedures, and the movement of the production line into a dedicated, government owned facility for systems storage, integration and checkout in order to provide sufficient capacity for future production demands.

Justification.val:
The FY 2020 enacted includes congressional rescission of $11.3 million to FY 2019 funding.  However, this rescission is not reflected on the P-40.


In FY 2021 UMCS will fund: 
-Procurement of hardware for an OCONUS CVN installation(FY19 NDAA requirement) 
   * 1 MD-5A control station consisting of 6 CDS, 2 CPS, 1 NPG, 1 NAS, and 1 Ship ICS
   * 1 ARC-210 Radio Communication System (RCS)
   * 1 MUOS capable communication system
   * Ancillaries
-Hardware components for one operational shore site
   * 1 MD-5A control station consisting of 6 CDS, 2 CPS, 1 NPG, 1 NAS, and 1 Shore ICS
   * 1 ARC-210 RCSs
   * 1 MUOS capable communication system
   * 4 Common Data Link (CDL) systems; this component is unique to shore site
   * 1 Ashore Routing Communication System (ARCS); this component is unique to shore site
   * Ancillaries
-Complete Ship Installation Drawings (SIDs) and begin installing Ship Change Documents (SCDs) for the first operational MQ-25 CVN 
-Procure installation material and 1 Video Management System (VidMS) for the CVN installation 
-Ship Check and initiation of SIDs for another CVN installation  
-Installation planning and continued preparation of design documentation for the operational shore sites; C4I integration personnel support this effort (operational network connectivity)
-Continued preparation of guidance documentation consisting of installation instructions and top-level drawings) for the FORD Class
-Modification and integration with externally managed Command, Control, Communication, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) systems to support MQ-25 operations
   * Support to facility and control station system design focusing on integration with the operational communications and networks infrastructure at the 3 shore site locations
   * Integration with shore site services (e-mail, chat, browsing, etc.) to support MQ-25
   * Design and network integration with Commercial Satellite Communications (SATCOM) system architecture to support MQ-25 
-Product Support and Assembly (i.e. Lead Systems Integration (LSI) activities) to assemble, integrate, checkout, and deliver UMCS hardware (MD-5, ARC-210, MUOS, etc.)
-Production Engineering Support that includes Systems Engineering and Program Management (SEPM) to include LSI functions and production planning
-Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) to fund organic logistics planning, creation of technical data packages, and create maintenance training documentation required for operational ship and shore systems

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 1.1.1 funds the procurement of Common Display Systems (CDS) supporting operational Unmanned Carrier Aviation (UCA) Mission Control System (UMCS) installations.
Cost Element 1.1.2 funds the procurement of Common Processing System (CPS) supporting Unmanned Carrier Aviation Mission Control Station (UMCS) installations.
Cost Element 1.1.3 funds the procurement of Network Processing Group (NPG) supporting operational MD-5 control station installations.

Cost Element 1.1.4 funds the procurement of Network Attached Storage (NAS), a production modification to the Network Processing Group (NPG) to support required system redundancy across The Unmanned Carrier Aviation Mission Control System (UMCS).
Cost Element 1.1.5 funds the procurement of Integrated Communication System (ICS) supporting operational MD-5A control station installations.
Cost element 1.1.6 funds the procurement of Integrated Communication Systems (ICS) supporting operational MD-5B shore control stations.
Cost Element 1.1.8 funds procurement of the ARC-210 Radio Communication System (RCS), which provides narrow band Line of Sight (LOS) command and control (C2) for the MQ-25.
Cost Element 1.1.9 funds procurement of the MUOS Capable Communication System, which provides narrow band Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) command and control (C2) using the MUOS satellites.
Cost Element 1.1.10 funds procurement of the Common Data Link (CDL) terminals required for the operational shore site.
Cost Element 1.1.11 funds procurement of the Ashore Routing Communication system networking equipment required for the operational shore site.
Cost Element 1.1.12 funds procurement of the ancillary Unmanned Carrier Aviation Mission Control Station (UMCS) support systems required for carrier and operational shore sites.

Cost Element 1.2.1 funds Ship Change Document (SCD) planning, design, tech data package, and installation labor of the UMCS systems aboard the NIMITZ and FORD class carriers.  This begins three years prior to each carrier availability where UMCS and MQ-25 installations are conducted and can occur across up to three availability periods. FY21 total cost increase compared to FY20 due to additional support needed for Hull Mechanical and Electrical (HM&E) and Interface Cabling and Support Equipment (IC&SE) tasking.

Cost Element 1.2.3 funds modification and integration with externally managed C4I systems to include Consolidated Afloat Networks and Enterprise Services (CANES), Automated Digital Networking System (ADNS), Ships Signal Exploitation Equipment (SSEE), Distributed Common Ground System - Navy (DCGS-N), Navy Tactical Common Data Link (NTCDL), Common Datalink System Tech Refresh (CDLS-TR), Wideband Military SATCOM, Commercial SATCOM, Mobile User Objective System (MUOS), Link 16, and others. FY21 total cost increase compared to FY20 due to a switch to a Navy Commercial SATCOM POR after security issues were identified by the Navy with the MQ-25 contractors commercial SATCOM selection.  This selection requires additional costs for non-recurring engineering, sustainment and subscription costs to non PoR satellite service

Cost Element 1.2.5 Product Support funding will include production planning (methodology), Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) for the MD-5 control station, and quality plan and procedures. NRE includes the assembly and delivery of the MD-5 control station. FY21 costs increased due to the significant increase in hardware procurements. In FY20, only 1 Video Management System (VidMS) was procured which requires minimal product support; while in FY21, 2 complete MD-5 control stations are being procured.
Cost Element 1.2.6 funds planning, integration, installation, and checkout of the MD-5B system with the operational shore site networks, communication, and infrastructure.
Cost Element 2.1.1 funds integration, licensing, and correction of deficiencies in the Stingray Operating Software Suite (SOSS), the UMCS software component.

Cost Element 3.1 (PES) The government is the Lead System Integrator (LSI) for the UMCS systems. Additionally, the PES required to perform the LSI role across this product line includes program, financial, schedule management, and production engineering. Includes CVN (NIMITZ and FORD) and Operational Shore Facility GOV and KTR support with production engineering management and preparation of technical documentation.
Cost Element 3.2 funds the organic logistics planning and execution across the UMCS product line for operational shore and carrier system support.
